content.html:
I'm not going to go on about the whys and wherefores surrounding getting started with Mastodon. I'll include some links at the end of this that go over all that.

I started to collect information to write this post and came across this excellent post: 10 quick Mastodon tips. It is a great overview and includes some nice graphics to explain things. I highly recommend reading it to familiarize yourself with how Mastodon works.

These tips and tricks are for once you've set up your account and now need to know what to get things done. They are a bit redundant if you read the link above but I'll leave them here anyway. I plan to add to this page as I find other useful tips.

Tips for Twitter Users

  • Add your Mastodon link to your Twitter profile
    • The format for this is @yourusername@yourmstodonserver. For example, mine is @techlifeweb@indieweb.social
  • Find your Twitter follow/followers on Mastodon
    • An easy way to do this is to use debirdify. debirdify uses the Twitter API to find any users you follow that are on Mastodon. All you do is authorize debirdify to access your Twitter account and it cans through looking for links to Mastodon in Twitter profiles (this is why it is important to link to Mastodon in your Twitter profile as above)
  • Enable a Tweetdeck-like interface on your laptop
    • Open Mastodon and then click Preferences > Appearance then check "Enable advanced web interface"
    • If you then click on a hashtag or search for one a new column will open. If you want to make that new column a permanent part of your interface, click the 'Show Settings' button at the top of the column. Then click Pin.
      • Once you pin it you can open the column settings again and add more hashtags. You can have it include any or all additional hashtags or block tweets that include certain hashtags.

Other things

  • Mastodon has it's own Thread Unroller
    • Just add @threadunroller@mastodon.social to a post in your thread and it will create a custom page of all the posts. Example here
  • Language preferences
    • In Mastodon's web interface and click on Other, you'll see a list of languages at the bottom you can use to control which posts you'll see.
  • There is an RSS feed of your posts aka Toots
    • You can find it at https://[server.name]/@[username].rss

Useful Links

  • Switching From Twitter to Mastodon | avoidthehack!
  • Sharing advice and assisting with the great Mastodon migration | by Mastodon Migration | Nov, 2022 | Medium
  • A Resource For Figuring Out The Fediverse - SethGoldstein.me

name: Indieweb How to PESOS from Twitter and POSE Elsewhere at the same time

content.html:
Websites built adhering to the specifications of the Indieweb allow you to easily post on your own site and syndicate that content elsewhere. Also known as POSSE. For example, I can create a post here and with some hidden microformats and the magic of webmentions I my content would be cross-posted or "syndicated" over to Twitter or Mastodon or wherever I tell it to go.

Similarly, I can do the reverse. Knowns as PESOS for Post Elsewhere then Syndicate on your Own Site. For example, I could make a tweet on Twitter then grab the link to that tweet and save it on this site as a link back to that Tweet.

You can easily use social sites without all this but the point here is owning your own content.

Let's take a deeper look at how PESOS would work. I make a Tweet like this one: https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097

Now I want to make a new post here on this site and tell the post that I syndicated it over to Twitter at that URL. The basic framework for that is to make a new post here and include:

<a class="syn-link u-syndication relsyn" rel="syndication" href="https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097"></a>

That doesn't look like much if you render it on a web page. No text would be visible. I like to take it a step further and add the text of that Tweet so that it makes more sense if you saw the post on my site here. Here is how I do that:

<p>Tweeted:<a class="syn-link u-syndication relsyn" rel="syndication" href="https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097"></a></p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Scott Kingery on Twitter: "The latest TechLifeWeb Daily is out! #tlwd https://t.co/aoktXCJdsN #breaking #secspeaks" / Twitter</p><a href="https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097"></a></blockquote>

That ends up looking like:

Tweeted:

Scott Kingery on Twitter: "The latest TechLifeWeb Daily is out! #tlwd https://t.co/aoktXCJdsN #breaking #secspeaks" / Twitter

Now let's take this one step further and instead of the above code we'll add a couple more bits to enable a cross-post aka POSSE over to Mastodon. That looks like this:

<p>Tweeted:<a class="syn-link u-syndication relsyn" rel="syndication" href="https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097"></a></p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr" class="p-bridgy-mastodon-content">Scott Kingery on Twitter: "The latest TechLifeWeb Daily is out! #tlwd https://t.co/aoktXCJdsN #breaking #secspeaks" / Twitter</p><a href="https://twitter.com/TechLifeWeb/status/1590424894017540097"></a></blockquote><a href="https://brid.gy/publish/mastodon"></a>

If you look closely, the extra bits are 

"p-bridgy-mastodon-content" in the <p> section right after blockquote

and 

<a href="https://brid.gy/publish/mastodon"></a> at the end of the whole block

When I publish my latest post, I also send a webmention to brid.gy which then take only the text in the P /P section after p-bridgy-mastodon-content and posts it over to Mastodon.

Here are the live examples:

My page where I posted the PESOS and POSSE code linking to the syndicated Tweet: https://techlifeweb.com/static/Note-2211091852.html

And the Mastodon post or Toot where only the text got sent: https://indieweb.social/@techlifeweb/109317256526331272

How all the webmention stuff works is beyond the scope of this post. brid.gy and indieweb..org are good sources to start understanding those bits.

The code block above is long, messy and easily mistyped. That's why I have bookmarklet in my browser so all I need to do is go to the url of the Tweet and click the bookmarklet and it will grab all the text and preformat everything for me. It looks like this if you want to copy it into your own bookmark:

javascript:void(prompt('To make an Indieweb SYNDICATED link of this tweet\nCopy the code below and paste it to a new entry on your site:','<p>Tweeted:<a class="syn-link u-syndication relsyn" rel="syndication" href="'+location.href+'"></a></p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr" class="p-bridgy-mastodon-content">'+document.title+'</p><a href="'+location.href+'"></a></blockquote><a href="https://brid.gy/publish/mastodon"></a>'));

While I've shown Twitter > My Site > Mastodon is could easily go elsewhere or from the reverse of that. You just have to get the u-syndication link pointed to the right place (e.g. your Mastodon Toot if that is where you started) and then, if you wanted to sent the text over to Twitter, you change the last bit to 

https://brid.gy/publish/twitter

Have fun!

Tweeted:

'+document.title+'

'));While I've shown Twitter > My Site > Mastodon is could easily go elsewhere or from the reverse of that. You just have to get the u-syndication link pointed to the right place (e.g. your Mastodon Toot if that is where you started) and then, if you wanted to sent the text over to Twitter, you change the last bit to https://brid.gy/publish/twitter Have fun!
